docs.abstract: Correction of Jan 27 article: Dr Frederica P Perera, lead author of study on effects of air pollution and smoking of fetuses, is woman
docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Jan. 27 about research on the effects of air pollution and smoking on fetuses referred incorrectly to the lead author of the study. Dr. Frederica P. Perera, director of the Columbia Center for Children's Environmental Health in New York, is a woman.

headline.main: On Tobacco Road, It's a Tougher Sell

docs.abstract: Brokers say buyers are increasingly reluctant to consider homes being sold by smokers; say smokers' homes take longer to sell and do not fetch optimum price; there is no legal requirement that sellers or their brokers dislose if current residents smoke, but masking or eliminating tobacco odor can be costly and difficult; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE residential real estate market may be sizzling -- but not so much, brokers say, if a smoker's home is the one for sale. ''Everything sells eventually, even horrible closet-size apartments,'' observed Frank Torre of the Corcoran Group, who markets condominiums and co-ops in Manhattan. ''But a place smelling like tobacco? It is going to take longer.''

headline.main: Ride During Moscow Rush Ends Under Pile of Bodies

docs.abstract: Bomb explodes on Moscow subway train during morning rush hour, killing at least 39 people and wounding more than 130; investigators suspect Chechen separatists are behind attack (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: After the explosion in her subway car, Anna A. Lvova clambered out without a scratch, but she said that was because she was buried under the dead. At rush hour on Friday morning, Ms. Lvova, 31, said she was standing and reading a magazine in the second car of a train on Moscow's green line as it began to speed north from the Avtozavodskaya station, near Moscow's center, toward the big Paveletskaya rail hub.
